cell.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.

Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.

div.head: 'BALLONS D'ESSAI"
div.p:
The Russian Press has been very active lately in demanding the instand despatch of a part, at least, of the Black Sea Squadron to join or follow Admiral Rodjestvensky's fleet on a cruise to Eastern waters. Greay Britain, according to most Russian journalists, is the sole Power that will make any diplomatic objections to the passing of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles by the Russian division, and Captain Klado, since then under fifteen days arrese, informs his public that the British foreign polocy is now a matter of snarls and grimaces, alarming but scarcely to be called dangerous. Whether the Black Sea Fleet is in a condition to reach Far Eastern waters we leave to naval experts to decide, but the calm assumption that Great Britain will permit a squadron to pass in defiance of treaty obligations and endanger the very existance of her ally, would be amusing were it not part of a scheme to sow dissention between the two naval Powers. The Muscovite Press, always awaiting inspiration, has shown remarkable unamity in denouncing the "perfidy" shown by England in her tretament of her unfortunate ally. The case of the Caroline, the fact that British shippers have industriously supplied the Port Arthur garrison with provisions, the shipping of coal for the Baltic Fleet from Cardiff, the placing of a Russian order of $150,000 for heavy guns with the firms of Vickers and Maxim, are all quoted as proofs of our guile, and the passage of the

Dardanelles will, in the opinion of Russian journalists, be viewed with resignation, if not with complacency, by a perjured Government.

"In vain is the net spread in the sight of the bird." The Japanese are unlikely to be duped by these statements or appalled by the menace of the Black Sea Squadron, and though Russian statesmen inform eager journalisrts that We shall astonish the world by out moderation in the hour of victory, the hour of victory has not yet come, and Japan remains unmoved in her determination to check the Russian advance on Korea and N. China. Meanwhile, the Dardanelles question may yet cause trouble. Austria is interedted in protecting the Russian ingress to the Mediterranean, but to the suzerains of Egypt the very possibility is unpleasant to think of. A Russian fleet allowed free ingress and egress to and from the Black Sea would enable the Tsar's Govermnent to levy blackmail on Constantinople, while the Power that is now in occupation in Egypt cannot be indifferent to the risk of a naval raid on Egypt or the Syrian Coast in the absense of the whole or part of the Mediterranean squadron. The naval balance of power has shifted North, our next naval combat may be in the Atlantic, and should the treaty clauses, that forbid the Black Sea Fleet to pass the Kavals, be ever aborgated, the fortification of Port-Said and Alexandria, or better, a large increase of the Mediterranean Squadron, will be necessary.

div.head: THE PHARMACY REGULATIONS
div.p: We understand that Sir Horace Pinching'd reply to the Cairo pharmacists' committee will be delivered to-day or to-morrow. It is being awaited with great interest, and it will be interesting to see whether its decisions satisfy the majority of those concerned. The point at issue netween the Sanitary Department and the pharmacists is this. Are persons who have no knowledge whatever of drugs and their properties to be allowed to control pharmacies? The pharmacists, for the most part, urge that this should be forbidden, and that, in accordance with the practice usual in all Continental countries, no person should be allowed to own a pharmacy without holding a pharmaceutical diploma. Sir Horace Pinching, on the other hand, takes the view that no such qualifications should be demanded of the proprietor qui proprietor, but that, should he have anything whatever to do with the management od the pharmacy or pharmacies which are his property, he must first satisfy the Sanitary Department that he possesses expert knowledge. Should he not possess this, he cannpt interfere in any way with the management of the shop, and must leave this to a qualified pharmacist. The Director-General of the Sanitary Department holds that these conditions will elsure the safety of the public as dar as is humanly possible, and quotes Englans and the United States as countries where the proprietor of a chemist's shop is not necessarily an expert, but where the management is all that concernt the articles solely is in expert hands. The pharmacists of Cairo seem inclined to argue that the conditions in these counteies differ widely from those in Egypt, and that in practice it will be difficult or impossible to prevent the interference of the proprietor, if he should be minded to interfere. Will an expert-assistant risk the loss of hisplace, of his proprietor chooses to overstep the limits laid down in the new Pharmacy Regulations?

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR
DESTRUCTION OF FLEET
FEELING IN RUSSIA

div.p: The publication in Russia of the destruction of the Port Arthur fleet, which was hithero unknown except to a small circle, created consternation. Admiral Rodjestvensky's mission is now regarded as foredoomed to disaster.

div.head: Admiral Rodjestvensky with 21 vessles has arrived here. (Reuter).

div.p: Twenty vessles of the Baltic Fleet have arrived. (Havas).

div.head: GENERAL NEWS
"SCENE” IN HUNGARIAN CHAMBER.
FURNITURE SMASHED.
div.p: In view of the resolve of the Premier, M. Tisza, to introduce new rules against the 2 obstruction of Deputies, the Opposition entered the House a quarter of an hour before the meeting was to take place. They smashed the Presidential dais and table, together with the ministerial chairs, to atoms. They drove out the attendants with legs from the tables. Four attendants were wounded. In consequence of this disturbance, no sitting was held. (R.)

BUDAPEST, December 13. The members of the Opposition forced an entrance into the Chamber of Representatives and, after having chased the Presidential guard out, they smashed the dais and the desks. The sitting was adjourned. (Havas.)
M. DE PLEHVE'S ASSASSINATION.
MURDERER SENTENCED.

ST. PETERSBURG, December 13. The trial of Sassonoff, the assassin of M. det Plehve, and his accomplice, Sirkoski, began here this afternoon. There was a great crowd in the approaches to the Law Courts, which were patrolled by the police. The garrison was ready, but no disturbance took place.
Sassonoff was condemned to penal servitude for life and Sikorski to 20 years. (Reuter.)

div.head: GUARANTEES.-
div.p: The public confidence is always in proportion to the given guarantees, and there is much truth in the saying, "A good name is better than riches." We may say that much of the success of the Berlitz schools is due to the universal reputation of its admirable method. The results already obtained in Egypt, by the pupils who have been learning English, French, German, Italian, etc., eto., are an ample proof of the success of these schools in Alexandria (26, Rue Eglise Copte), and at Cairo (1, Sharia Kamel). (Advt.).

A. L. M. & D. S.-On Monday next, 19th inst., Mr. Atwood will lecture at the Scotch High School, in the Missala quarter, on "A Great Philanthropic Work in London.” We understand that the kind of work that formed the subject of our leading article last Saturday will be fully dealt with by the lecturer, who will have much to say of great importance to all interested in philanthropic work, espe. cially that done in the direction of rescuing destitute and waif children from their wretched surroundings, and giving them the chance of becoming respectable members of society. We hope to see a large attendance of members of the Alexandria Literary, Musical, and Dramatic Society and their friends. Members will be admitted free, non-members on payment of P.T. 2.

div.head: YOUSBASHI ARMSTRONG'S DEATH
div.p: The greatest astonishment has been caused owing to the circumstances attending the death of Yousbashi Armstrong, which, as we announced on Monday, took place at the German Deaconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, on Sunday. Only a few days ago the deceased was getting on well, and wrote to his friends that he was on the way to recovery from the attack { scarlet fever from which he had been suffering. He was judged by his doctor to be convalescent and had been allowed to see some of his acquaintances.

The question at once occurs by what mishance he could have caught one of the most horrible forms of infectious malady known to humanity, for the small-pox to which he fell victim was the most loathsome type of that ill disease. Lately he had written to his friends full of hope as to his speedy departure from the hospital. When, therefore, it was announced last week that he had contracted a fresh disease, the news was received with astonishment. He was so much liked, and such a good type of a young Englishman, that the circumstances attending his sudden death have caused a great deal of poignant interest to a large circle of his friends and acquaintances in the English colony here. But in justice to the German Hospital at Alexandria it may be ated that in England no small-pox hospital is considered safe within a distance of half a mile so infectious is that disease. A case of smallpox was being treated at the hospital while Yousbashi Armstrong was convalescent, and he must have caught the infection in the air, -at least so it is presumed.

div.head: PRESENTATION TO MR. CHATAWAY
div.p: The committee of the members of the Importers Association of Alexandria presented The following address to Mr. Chataway at the Alexandria Municipality at noon to-day :
A WILLIAM PERCEVAL CHATAWAY LE COMMERCE D'IMPORTATION D'ALEXANDRIE

Monsieur,--Les élus de la ville d'Alexandrie, vous ayant appelé à de plus hautes fonctions, nous a paru à nous, négociants importateurs, qui vous avons suivi depuis votre entrée à la douane Locale, qu'il était de notre devoir de venir vous apporter le témoignage de notre Profonde estime en même temps que nos vives Félicitations. Servir le Gouvernement avec elle, en faisant toujours respecter les règlements avec une imperturbable équité, fut toujours votre rôle, mais vous avez toujours su appliquer la Loi avec une telle bienveillance dans les procédés, vous avez montré dans vos rapports avec nous, une telle urbanité et une i juste compréhension de vos devoirs, que vous avez conquis les profondes sympathies de tout le commerce dont nous sommes aujourd'hui kas interprètes et dont nous sommes chargés de vous transmettre les sincères rendements. Ce sont là des traditions que vous avez créées, et qui, nous en sommes certains, subsistent toujours. En vous disant adieu, ce n'est que la perspective d'un heureux avenir pour vous qui atténue seule les regrets que nous éprouvons de votre changement de situation.
Le Comité ; Attilio Ninci, Kamel bey Teymur,
Auguste Alby, Robert J. Rolo,
H. Steinemann, G. G. Zibilich.
The signatures of the subscribers follow.
M.Attilio Ninci made the following speech in presenting the address:

Monsieur, - Je suis heureux que mes collègues du Comité élu par les diverses branches du Commerce d'Importation de notre Ville tiennent bien vouloir me charger de prendre la parole pour vous offrir ces souvenirs et teintes de sympathie que nous vous prions d'accepter à l'occasion de votre départ comme Directeur Local de la Douane d'Alexandrie. Plus que mes paroles, l'adresse, signée par tous les souscripteurs, que nous avons l'honneur de vous présenter, vous exprimera mieux encore les sentiments et les vifs regrets que vous avez su inspirer au Commerce d'Importation en particulier. S'il ne nous a pas été permis de nous acquitter plus tôt du mandat dont nous étions chargés, ce retard est attribuable à l'exode estival d'abord, et, surtout, au désir des Membres du Comité d'être ici tous présents.

Monsieur Chataway, en prenant congé de 'ous, nous pouvons vous assurer que nos meilleurs voeux vous accompagnent dans vos nouvelles fonctions et que tous ceux qui ont eu le plaisir de se trouver en relations avec vous comme Directeur des Douanes, garderont le las agréable souvenir de votre trop bref pasage dans cette Administration.
Afterwards the committee presented the following gifts to the late Director of Local Customs :
A magnificent table service in massive silver. A cheque for L.E. 150.
A parchment address with reliefs in old silver.
An artistic work by Kerchmeyer representing the Customs Administration's façade and the offices of Mr. Chataway.

div.head: MALACHITE IN SINAI.
div.p: Professor Reisner, the well-known Egyptologist, writes to us from the Pyramids, where, as we announced, he is conducting some in"teresting excavations. He draws our attention to the fact that Professor Flinders Petrie's interest in the malachite mines of Sinai is purely archäological, and his present expedition, undertaken as usual on behalf of the Egypt Exploration Fund and approved. by that society, has a scientific purpose only. Our announcement of the professor's expedition to the malachite mines did not necessarily imply that his object was commercial instead of antiquarian. We expressed a hope that the expedition would result in reviving the export of that beautiful stone, for in Egypt, where every new development is only a re-discovery, the antiquary must precede the exploiter, as was the case with the ancient gold mines.

div.head: SINAI INSCRIPTIONS
div.p: A very interesting work is to be issued in Paris shortly dealing with the Egyptian | antiquities in the Sinaitic peninsula. The ancient Egyptian inscriptions are numerous there, but no complete description of them has yet been published. Lepsius and Lottin de Laval, about 1850, issued the first collection of Sinaitic inscriptions, and an English expedition in 1868 published some photographic reproductions of their discoveries. That there are many other finds awaiting the careful explorer silenced by the comparatively recent discoveries of Euringer and Borchatt, who, on a brief visit to the old mining districts of the peninsula, found a number of new inscriptions. M. Weill had for a long time believed that an important collection of documents from the English mission of 1868 was to be found in the British Museum, and be set about a search there which ended in the discovery of a splendid series of inscriptions which had been lying neglected for 30 years. This collection is to be republished by M. Weill and it will form ope of the finest Egypto| logical works ever published.

div.head: A SUCCESSFUL SEASON
div.p: The present season at Helouan promises to be one of the best this famous health resort has ever known.

Among the latest arrival at the Grand Hotel we notice Baron and Baroness Menasce, of Alexandria, their three children, and suite, Mr. H. W. Hodges, Cairo Mr. and Mrs. Chester Master, England, Mr. C.J. R. Haswell, England, Mme. Bam Kellevink, Holland, and Mr. and Mrs. Lee, Boston, U.S.A..
Mr., Mrs. and Miss Sargent, also of Boston, have arrived and taken up their old quarters. This, we believe, is the fourth successive year that they have spent the winter at Helouan.
The Hotel des Bains reports are also good, this comfortable house being already full.
The Tewfik Palace Hotel has recently welcomed back some of its former visitors, including Major-General Lance, C. B., and Mrs. Lance.
After & course of treatment at the Sulphur Baths, Lady Loveson-Gower, and her son, Mr. Frederick Loverson-Gower M.P, for Sutherlandshire, left the Grand Hotel Helouan yesterday for a trip to Luxor.
The Hon. G. Calthorpe, Mr. Shore, and Dr. Tunnicliffe also left yesterday after a few weeks' visit. to the Grand Ho 31.

Amongst those shortly expected at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, are Irs. H. Wynne Finch, Miss Elizabeth Rich Mr. Edwin G. Owles, Mr. and Mrs. Bullock Workman, Major I. Adcock, M.D., Miss Netty Lovisa ,White, Capt. and Mrs. Hancox, Mr. and Mrs. F. F. Morley, Miss H. Rossiter, Mr. and Mrs. Craven, Mr. Whitmarsh, Mrs. Atkins, Mr. and Mrs. Willaby, Miss C. Moore, Mr. R. Page, Mrs. and Miss Robertson

div.head: VISIT OF THE INTERIOR ADVISER
div.p: Mr. Machell arrived here by last night's train and made an official inspection of the town this morning accompanied by the Moudir. At 2.30 he left for Lahoon, taking with him Major Elgood, Inspector for Fayoum.

Mr. Machell did not have time to go through the province and visit the different villages in order to ascertain if the inhabitants are contented, or to hear any complaints they might want to make. He only saw the town, which of course was made read for his expected visit. He will spend the night in his dahabieh at Sidment el Gohel and is expected to reach Cairo to-morrow.

div.head: THE GHAFFIR QUESTION.
div.p: It is now proposed to appoint ghaffirs both for day and night duty and to employ retired soldiers for the service. It is understood that this plan is approved by the Adviser,

div.head: IRRIGATION.
div.p: Mr. Clowes, the newly-appointed Inspector-General for Upper Egypt, is expected here to-night. I understand that an Englishman is to replace the native moudir of the Fayoum Irrigation works, and that the pay of the district engineers is to be increased next year. This should put a stop to their receiving backsheesh, and anyone taking it should in future be severely punished.

A Commission for the adjustment of the land taxes; composed of Mr. McKillop, the Finance inspector, president, and a staff of maoween, has arrived here with a view to add Gusting the land taxes of the locality. The maoween were, some of them, stationed in the three markazes of Keneh, Kous, and Luxor. Mr. McKillop is making a tour of inspection of the work of the maoween in these markazes. It is said the commission will complete the adjustment of the Keneh Mordirieh land taxes within 7 months, i.e., by next June.

Another commission is to be appointed after this one has finished its labours. It will be composed of the Sub-Moudir, as president, and two or three experienced codehs, to enquire into any complaints that may be made by agriculturists in connection with the increase of taxes on their lands.
Mr. Shinuda Magarius, the consular agent. of Austria-Hungary, has died at his residence at Luxor. Much regret is felt by all who knew this gentleman at the loss sustained by his death.

A large number of Sudanese cattle and sheep are being sold in the market here. The animals are in great demand among the butchers as well as the farmers, owing to the great scarcity of cattle consequent on the plague's ravages.
It is hoped that these imports will have some effect in lowering the price of meat, which has reached an unprecedentedly high price.

div.head: HELOUAN REGIMENTAL SPORTS
div.p: The officers of the Royal Engineers, who are now encamped on the grounds adjoining the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, have issued invitations for a sport meeting which is to take place on Saturılay next, commencing at 2 p.m. An orchestra will be in attendance on the grounds and the grand-stand of the Helouan Sporting Club will be reserved for visitors. Tea and refreshments will be served in the magnificent lounge of the Tewfik Palace.

In connection with these sports, visitors are reminded that the "Declame" luncheon (BT. J 12) will be served at one o’clock at the Tewfik Palace Hotel. Trains leave Babel-Louk station at 9.10 am., 10.10 a.m., and 12.10 pm. Special cloak-rooms will be reserved for ladies.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demi)
Malgré la hausse de ce matin tout fait prévoir qu'il n'y aura pas de reprise sérieuse ayant la fin janvier ou le commencement de février.

Les motifs, en effet, qui ont déterminé la débâcle actuelle, ne sont pas de ceux qui disparaissent en un jour. Il faudra à notrmarché un mois ou deux au moins pour se relever. Les gros spéculateurs ayant subi des pertes énormes en coton ont du vendre leurs paquets de titres. L'affluence des vendeurs à la corbeille a malheureusement coïncidé avec la liquidation de fin de mois es avec l'approche des fêtes du premier de l'an. Une baisse s'en est suivie qui a jeté la panique parmi la foule des petits spéculateurs. Si l'on ajoute qu'à cette époque du l'année les Affaires sont mortes, que le négociants arrêtent leurs comptes et réklisent pour liquider avant de communiquer les comptes de l'exercice suivant, on comprend jusqu'à un certain point la mauvaise humeur da marché et la baibee continu inévitable qui doit se produire lorsque tou. le monde peut se défaire de titres qu: personne ne se soucie d'acquérir. Aussi peut-on se dissimuler que A défiance a gagné les plus optimistes à tel point que les valeurs les plus solides elles-mêmes sont dépréciées.
Cette tendance subite et générale à réaliser a rendu la liquidation de fin du mois très laborieuse et n'a pu qu'aggraver la situation déja existante.
Il est juste d'ajouter qu'un certain nom. bre de détenteurs s'efforcent d'enrayer la baisse et qu'ils y réussissent en partie.
Les marchés européens suivent pour les valeurs égyptiennes le mouvement local e. Ils accusent eux aussi une baisse sensible.

Disons encore que la hausse de la fin du mois dernier avait été quelque peu exagérée, que la spéculation entraînée par un courant de baisse irrésistible était un peu trop abandonnée. La baisse de Nuw. York a été le coup de foudre qui a ramené les exaltés à une plus juste appréciation des choses.

Comme cette débâcle est dûe à des motifs qui pour la plupart auront disparu en février prochain, que le coton lui-même, initial de tout le mal, aura probablement regagné du terrain, on s'attend généralement pour toute date à une bonne reprise et à un redoublement d'activité.
Le marché, après sa dégringolade d'hier après-midi, a repris un peu de matin sui toute la ligne.
La Banque Nationale a ouvert à 21 3/8; une demi-heure après, elle atteignant x1 18/16 ; elle, clôture à 21 7/8 vendeurs.
Da même l'Agricole qui cotait 9 5/8 vendeurs est remontée ensuite à 9 7/8.

Et ainsi de suite pour la plupart des valeurs mouvementées; la Delta Land reprend à 37,16 vendeurs, la Daïra à 21 1/4 acheteurs, la Filature à 13/16 Vundtub, Is Salt &od Soda à 87/6 acheteurs, la Banque d'Athènes à 123 1/4 vendeurs et les Privilégiés Tramways a 138 acheteurs
D'autre part, la Orown twery tumb. à 206 nominal et la Bdserie des Pyro miden a 108 vendeurs. ·
Les Cotton Milis fléchissent également À 6/9, coura purement nominal.
En baisse aussi l'Anglo-american Nil. à 4 1/4 et la Delta Light à 14 1/4.
Le nombre des affaires á 6 é relativement considérable. La corbeille des cotun avait été complètement désertée à un moment donné.
Cette reprise, provenant de ce que les spéculateurs au découvert ont racheté ou qu'ils avaient vendu ces jours derniers, ne sera probablement que momentanée.

div.head: SAISIE D'ANTIQUITES
div.p: Avant-hier à 8 h. am, un attroupement inusité a été remarqué à l'entrée du cara col de l'Esbekieh. Les passante employés de maisons de commerce ou fonctionnaire du gouvernement, curieux de savoir quel événement 8:08 rationnel retenait les lois. sifs Box, abords du district de police, descendaient du tramway, se mêlaient à la foule, jetaient un regard et rejoignaient ni en courant le véhicule. Les plus curieux interrogeaient et apprenaient que des charrettes qui contenaient ces momies avaient été saisies Il Y avait aussi des ustensiles et d'autres objets antiques.
Le propriétaire, qui surveillait le transport, a été arrêté par la police. Il a déclaré avoir acheté ces pièces au Service des antiquités et les avoir gardées pendant un certain temps à son domicile.
Le service des antiquités a été avisé et une enquête est ouverte pour établir s'il y a bi n schat on contrebande.

En réali é il n'y kv.it pas de momies volé a on ach té sinais de vieux facho phags gang importance que le propriétaire N'en ait procuré à prix d'argent. Quant aux ustensil.g, ils n'étaient qu'une imitation des antiquités L'enquête l'est bien démontrée, et l'individu soupçonné de contrebande a été remis en liberté.

div.head: Comites Municipaux
div.p: Cet apres-midi, a 3 heures, le conseil l'estimation se reunira au Palais Municipal pour trancher diverses questions concernant des excendents du tanzim. Cette reunion sera suivie d'une seance de Comite fiancier ou sera discute le projet du bidget pour 1905, presente par I'Administrateur de la Municipalite.

div.head: Alexandria Water Company
DIVIDENDE INTERIMAIRE
div.p: Un dividende intérimaire de deux shellings et six pence par action de $5 et de dix shellings par action de £ 20 est payable le 15 courant, sur présentation des coupons de cette échéance à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ld, à Alexandrie,

Afia de donner suite à la décision de l'Assemblée Général, Extraordinaire du 27 | Mars 1889, par laquelle chaque action de | $20 fut convertie en 4 actions de £5, et à la demande du Book Exchange de Londres, qui en donnant la côte any actions de la Compagnie a exigé que toutes les actions de la Vie formeraient partie d'une seule série de Nos. de 1 à 100,000; il devient | absolument nécessaire de présenter tous les titres de £ 20, afin d'y timbrer les nouveaux numéros et d'attacher aux titres une nouvelle feuille de coupons représenta. Bentant quatre actions chacune portant | aussi des numéros.

Pour cette raison MM. les porteurs des titres de £ 20 sont priés de présenter à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ld. à Alexandrie, leurs titres de £ 20 en même temps que le coupon du 16 courant, et la Banque lear donnera en échange un certificat de dépôt, contre le retour duquel les titres de £ 20 seront rendus aux propriétaires, munis des nouveaux numéros et coupong. 25036-4.4

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, December 8. The Market this week has been depressed, and only a small business has resulted ; quotations being reduced to @ 7o for current qualities and to for Fine and also Upper Egypt.
A good business has been done in Egyptian Futures, the following being the latest values:Dec. 7.31 Feb. 7.0 Apl. 6..58 Jan. 7.10 Mar. 6.60 May 6.58.

American Futures. The Market this week has undergone a very serious experience, the Bureau' estimate of the Crop, amounting to 12,162,000 bales, produced a panic, enormous quantities of Cotton were thrown over, and prices fell 50 points on one day (Monday). Since then, there has been a slow re-adjustment of values, with, however, many weak moments; for instancó on Tuesday, when prices fell 10 points, the current month touching 4.06. To-day, with a steadier feeling, values are fully 10 points above the lowest rates, but still 57 @ 49 points below those of last Thursday. The position in one of great difficulty; prices would appear to have fallen to a point of comparative safety considering the good trade conditions and the absolutely depleted supplies at the commencement of the season, but a Crop of 12 millions, probably more, promises & supply at least half a million in excess of the most liberal requirements, and it is just this unknown surplus that may check | speculation and cause present prices, moderate as they are, to be too high for the absorption of the superabundant supply.
The latest quotations are, delivery :Dec. 4.12 Feb./Mar. 4.23 May/June 4.33 | Dec./Jan. 4.12 Mar./Apl. 4.27 June/July 4.35 Jan./Feb. 4.18 Apl./May 4.30 July/Aug. 4.37

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
div.p: We would call the attention of persons interested in | Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, Now Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: MAHMOUD SAMI PASHA EL BAROUDI
(SPECIAL MEMOIR)
div.p: If it were the duty of a newspaper to simplicitly obey the maxim, De mortuis mil nisi bonum, the death of Mahmoud Sami · Pasha el Baroudi, which we announced in Vonday's issue, should pass without any comment. But the sinister part which the late Pasha played in bringing about the crisis in the history of modern Egypt, known locally as the "Events," is part and parcel of the history of this country, and we must perforce give sovne account of his deeds. Mahmoud Pasha Sami owed his surname of El Baroudi --the · powder maker--to the fact that his father was Director of the Powder Mill. He had nothing striking about his appearance, except an unpleasant squint, coupled with the habit of never looking into one's face when speaking, By no means particularly gifted, or even dis· tinguished as an administrator, he, nevertheless, succeeded in climbing to the top of the tree, thanks to a certain shrewdness and a remarkable talent for intrigue.sUtterly unprincipled and ready to do anything to gain his ends, he successfully traded on the weaknesses and blunders of his betters, and he had the reputation of never having missed an opportunity of ingratiating himself with men at the helm. In turn the servilo courtier, first of Ismail, to whom he owed almost everything and whom he professed to worship, and then of Tewfik, he was of course a fervent satellite of" Cherif, Riaz, and Nubar, according to the political barometer of the day. Always courting the dispenser of favours, the man in power, it could be expected that he would join "the colonels” as soon as Arabi was likely to become master of the situation. It mattered indeed little that he was a member of Cherif's cabinet, that he had pledged himself to stand and fall with mischief ;--such trifling considerations had · no weight; and now we know that Baroudi was the son of the military conspiracy against his colleagues. But we must not anticipate events,

Educated at Constantinople at Ismail's expense, he gained his "spurs" at the Grand Vizierate, where he remained for seven years as a clerk, and on his return to Egypt he lingered for some years in subordinate positions until his marriage with a daughter of Ismail's dada, or neroe, obtained him, in addition to a handsome dower, the position of aide-de camp to his Highness.

Thus launched into the official world he complacently sunned himself. in his generous master's favor, until a domestic mishap threw a cloud over his fortunes, and deprived him for a time of the golden advantages of what he so pleased to call the vitiated atmosphere of courts. It appears that he discovered one day a tender weakness of his better half for a young and enterprising musician ; and not satisfied with killing the disturber of matrimonial harmony, he likewise murdered the mother of his wife's lover and her slave. As to his wife and mother-in-law, they had to start for a trip up the White Nile, "whence no one returns." Ismail Pasha frowned, he was fond of his dada, but Mahmoud Sami managed to get his cause so ably pleaded that he was soon allowed to return to Cairo, and passing a sponge over this little episode his Highness pardoned the ferocious Othello. Nay, his friends obtained for him after a few months the appointment of Arzoulnaldji or receiver of the petitions at Abdeen Palace. Once again in the stirrups, Mahmoud did not lose his time, and aware of the value of powerful connections, and the influence women have in pushing husbands to the front, ha was lucky enough to obtain the hand of one of Mansour Pasha's sisters, thus becoming brother in law to Ismail's favorite daughter, HH. the Princess Tewhida.

Moreover, a marriage into the rich and powerful Yegen family secured him the patronage of such men as Haidar, Barud, Kalil Pasha Yegan, Ali Pasha Cherif, and others. Sent twice to Candia with dispatches, this feat gained him the rank of colonel, and during the last Russo-Turkish war he commanded a regiment of cavalry ander Prince Hanan, who is said to have had a poor idea of the gallant colonel's military capacity.

On his return to Cairo it happened that an unscrupulous instrument was wanted for the part of Prefect of Police, and Mahmoud Sami volunteering his services were accepted. In his new position he found opportunities for making friends with those he had been appointed to watch ; in fact it is stated that he knew all about the contemplated military movement of February 1st, 1879. At any rate he managed to keep Ismail, as well as the Wilson ministry, completely in the dark; yet so well did he ohntile his cards, that he was soon after made a Minister; in fact, Cherif had to accept him as Minister of Wakfs and of Public Instruction.

lu this capacity he countersigned, in August 1879, with his colleagues, what is commonly called "Cherif's Constitution," and which forms, as we know, the basis of the present Organic law. With the other ministers, he pledged himself to stand or to fall by the reform project of his chief, but Mahmoud Sami deserted his party as soon as the non-acceptance of Cherif's proposals obliged the cabinet to resign. "So turning his back on notables and constitution he went over to Riaz, who gave him the portfolio of the Wakfs, which he exchanged on February 1st, 1881, for that of Minister of War. The great opportunity of his life now arrived. When Arabi formed the Camarella amongst the native Egyptian officers, which made the "three colonels the chiefs of the native military organisation, the most important recruit outside the ranks of the army whose services were enlisted was Mahmoud Pasha Sami, the Minister of War. He was an Egyptian of Turkish descent, who saw an opportunity of advancing his own fortunes by associating himself with the conspiracy, and who, after the wont of Turks in Egypt, soon made himself the master of his fellow-conspirators. He soon di-played his consummate treachery to the Khedive, for it was by his advice that the fellaheen officers issued a protest against the reduction of the array, and insisted on the post of Minister of Wer being entrusted to a native Egyptian. A cabinet council was held, at which Mahmoud Suur was present, and at which it was decided to summon the colonels to a meeting at the Kasr el Nil barracks, on the plea of discussing their protest, and to arrest them if they persisted in their demands. Mabmoud Sami at once communicated the intentions of the Ministry to his confederates, and it was arranged that the regiments under their command should march on Kasr el Nil at the time appointed for the meeting and rescue their commanding offiçers if any attempt was made to effect their arrest. The Khedive was betrayed, a mutiny followed, and as he had no troops on whom he could rely, he had to yield to the demand of the mutinéers. Mahmoud Sami, as Minister of War, did everything in his power to secure the support of the army, The Khedive grew alarmed at the way his personal authority was being undermined and he suddenly replaced Mahmoud Sami at the War Office by his own brother-in-law, ' Daoud Pasha, a Circassian. Another meeting followed and Arabi only consented to withdraw his troops in the Ministry were dismissed. Cherif Pasha, much against his will, consented to accept the presidency of this new administration, in which Mahmoud Sami resumed his old position of Minister of War. In vain did Cherif Pasha protest, in vain did he point out that Mahmoud Sami had deserted the national and liberal cause, in vain did he declare that no confidence could be placed in a man who was one day for, and the next against, constitutional institutions. It was all useless, for Mahmoud had bewitched his military patronse and his appointment was made a conditio sine quá non, From the first he betrayed his chief and his colleagues in the Ministry, and secretly encouraging the intrigues of his subordinates, he made the War Office the centre of a conspiracy of which he and Arabi were the promoters, and which had for its sole object the overthrow of Cherif Pasha. How the Prime Minister fell, and Mahmoud Sami stepped into his place, how he gained the support of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, and how, with Arabi as his Minister of War, the administration of Egypt passed absolutely and entirely out of the hands of the Khedive, are known to everyone who takes any interest in the history of modern Egypt for the events which followed led to the bombardment of Alexandria and the British Occupation of Egypt.

Four years ago El Baroudi was pardoned by the Khedive and on his return to Egypt from Ceylon was received by his Highness at Koub beh. The Khelive restored to him all his civil rights, authorising him to buy and sell land and to administer his property. Sami Pasha had for several years been afflicted with blind ness. In the latter years of his life fortune favored him. Three years ago he bought feddans of land at Manial for the sum of LE 4,000 ; to-day they are worth over L.E.30.000 He recently let his house at Darb el Gamamiz, where the Mehkemeh Sharieh installed, to the Government, and repaired his residence at Bab-el-Khalk, which is one of the finest in Cairo.

Sami Pasha was a well-known Arabic poet and a man of letters of no mean order. During the last two years he had published four bulky volumes giving extracts from eight of the greatest Arabic poets of modern times. His funeral on Tuesday was of an imposing character, being attended by a large gathering of natives

div.head: ESCAPE IN SUEZ CANAL
div.p: Twelve men of that regiment of dare-devils, the Foreign Legion, have successfully deserted in a peculiarly audacious way. The Messageries Maritimes steamer Cao Bang was passing the Suez Canal, outward bound, with troops for French Indo-China. Apparently a number of foreign legionaries on board had had enough of military service, for which, of course, all the men of the corps have volunteered, as none are of French nationality, or else they had changed their minds regarding the attractions of the Far East. Anyhow, one afternoon seven of them jumped overboard. One was caught by the steamer's screws and went under. The six others, escaping sharks, swam safely ashore, where they proceeded to wave their caps derisively at the boat. Two hours later six more foreign legionaries followed suit, two of them being recaptured and put in irons, while the four others successfully joined the six already on land. The next morning two more men of the corps jumped overboard, and escaped both pursuers and sharks. It is not known what has become of the twelve deserters who landed and were left behind.

div.head: EGYPT AND CRETE
div.p: In the Anntual of the British School at Athens, Mr. Evans calls attention to the evidence of close relations between Crete and Egypt-clumps of crocuses used in decorations as adaptation of clumps of lotus flower, and a painted jar with papyrus reliefs; but he does not touch the important question of the relation between the earlier and the later civilization of Crete. Evidently he is waiting for new evidence.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Sir Perey Girouard, K.C.M.G., who is so well known in Egypt in connection with railway work, has just been promoted Lieutenant Colonel from Captain and Brevet-Major in the Royal Engineers, for "distinguished services of an exceptional nature other than in the field.”This is Sir Percy's reward for his brilliant railway work during and after the South African campaign.

Major and Brevet Colonel G. G. Cunningham, J.B., D.S.O., Royal Scots, second in command of the 2nd Battalion at Kamptee, has been promoted lieutenant-colonel of the 1st Battalion at Woking. Colonel Cunningham has had a varied campaigning career, having seen active service in Egypt against Arabi's army, where he was twice wounded, and with the Egyptian
Army gained repute on the Nile with Earle's force and the operations of the Sudan Frontier force, and in West Africa he participated in no fewer than five expeditions.

Captain H. W. Pearson, Royal Engineers, who for some time has been acting as Staff Captain in the Department of the Director of Military Operations, goes back to Egypt for service with the Khedive's army. He went Through the Tirah expedition 1897-98 and the Boxer campaign 1901-02.
Owing to the increase of the Military Mounted Police necessitated by the stationing of an entire squadron in Egypt, the establishment of that force has been considerably augmented.

The S.S. Plassy left Southampton on the 6th Inst. for Bombay with some 800 troops-chiefly artillerymen-and details on board for various batteries and companies in India. The Plassy is due to reach Bombay about the 30th inst. Leaving Berbuy, on the 6th prox. with time. expired men she is timed to arrive at Southampton on the 28th prox.

The net result of all changes which are being effected in the navy at home and abroad will be that in the course of a few weeks' time Great Britain will have concentrated in home vaters and in the Atlantic a huge naval 'striking force” of an irresistible power capable of smashing any combination against it. In short, it is a complete triumph for the "blue water school" whose first tenet is not detence but the meeting of an enemy on its own shores, and. naval supremacy in the Atlantic, the great lighway of European nations.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON
IN THE CONGO FREE STATE
div.p: For the next plantation the Congo Free State Government has been assured of the co-operation of some planters who have practised for some years in the culture of cotton and the preparation of this product in Egypt, and all the measures taken by the Government | promise well with regard to the plantations which will be undertaken next February | The climate can be compared with that of the Egyptian regions, although the rainfall may not be considerable, since it does not reach two metres, but there are even below the Equator periods of eight weeks when the rains are exceptional (from mid-January to mid-March, June and July).

SERVICES SANITARES
AVIS
div.p: Il est rappelé aux vendeurs des substances vénéneuses déjà autorisés en vertu de l'arrêté du 13 Juin 1891 qu'il est nécessaire d'obtenir le nouvelles autorisations dans le délai de 90 Jours à partir de la publication du Décret du 15 Septembre * qui eut lieu dans le Journal Officiel français le 19-Septembre 1904 et dans le Journal officiel arabe le 21 du même mois. Les autorisations qu'ils détiennent actuellement seront donc nulles après le 21 Décembre 1904.

L'examen qu'auront à subir les vendeurs de substances vénéneuses, conformément à l'art. 12, avant d'obtenir les autorisations nécessaires, aura lieu pour la ville d'Alexandrie le lundi de chaque mois à l'Hôpital du Gouvernement.
Exceptionnellement les premiers examens auront lieu dans le dit établissement les 14 et 19 Décembre 1904 à 9 h. a.m.
Les personnes sollicitant l'autorisation de faire le commerce des substances vénéneuses devront justifier des connaissances suivantes :
1° Connaître toutes les dispositions du Règle. ment sur la vente des substances vénéneuses.
2° Savoir lire et écrire sous dictée les noms de toutes les substances mentionnées dans le Tableau II annexé au Règlement.
3° Connaître parfaitement les poids et mesures du système métrique.

4° Savoir distinguer 15 articles au moins des substances suivantes : Cobalte, (arsen-métallique), acide arsénieux, Realgar (sulfure rouge d'arsenic), Auripigment (sulfure jaune d'arsenic), Acide hydrocyanique, Cyanure de potasse, Bichlorure de mercure, Bisulfate de mercure, Oxide mercurique jaune, Oxide mercurique rouge, Acétate de plomb, Sulfate de zinc, Chlorure de zinc, Tartre stibié, Acétate de cuivre, Phosphore, Chloroforme, Acide picrique, Acide oxalique.
5o Expliquer l'usage des substances mentionnées dans le Tableau II et dire comment elles doivent être renfermées et étiquetées.
6° Pouvoir tenir régulièrement les registres pour la vente des substances vénéneuses.

Les personnes qui subiront avec succès l'examen précité pourront obtenir l'autorisation nécessaire pour la vente des substances vénéneuses. Toutefois l'autorisation ne sera délivrée aux intéressés qu'après que l'autorité sanitaire ce sera assurée que le local destiné à la vente est bien aéré et non humide, qu'il est propre et que de nom de la personne autorisée est | lisiblement écrit sur le devant du local. | Les personnes désirant obtenir l'autorisation i de vendre une ou diverses substances vénéneuses
devront être tenues à distinguer seulement les articles pour lesquels l'autorisation est sollicitée, et dans le cas où l'autorisation est accordée,
il sera nettement stipulé sur la permission que | le porteur est autorisé à vendre seulement ces
substances et aucune autre. 1 Alexandrie, le 6 Décembre 1904.
L Administrateur, (Signó) W. P. L HATAWAY

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette will be pleased to receive communication dealing with matters of local interest, for publication. Notes of events occuring in the Provinces are especially welcome.
All communications should be sent to "THE EDITOR," and be accompanied by the Writer's Name and Address, not necessarily for in sertion, but as a guarantee of good faith.
The Editor will not undertake to return any contribution unaccompanied by a stamp and return address.
